title: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam freezes travel Wuhan shuts schools cancels public events
story: Share this article All mainland arrivals to Hong Kong will now need to sign health declaration forms, she added, while public events including a new year gala and next month's marathon would be axed.She added: 'We haven't seen serious and widespread infections (in Hong Kong), but we are taking this seriously and we hope to be ahead of the epidemic,' Lam said.Â Hong Kong has a recent experience of deadly viral outbreaks and nearly 300 people were killed by SARS in 2003, a tragedy that left a profound psychological impact on one of the most densely populated places on earth.Â          As part of the upgraded threat level, leader Carrie Lam (left with health chiefÂ Gabriel Leung) said schools that are currently on Lunar New Year holidays will remain closed until February 17 and education authorities have asked universities to extend leave for students         People wear masks as they eat at the Hong Kong International Airport in Hong KongThe outbreak also comes at a sensitive time for Lam, who currently boasts record low approval ratings after seven months of pro-democracy protests.'We must stand united so that we can prevent and control the disease,' she said, in a nod to the political unrest.The often violent protests have battered Hong Kong's reputation for stability and helped tip it into recession, with the recent virus outbreak compounding the city's economic woes.Hospitals are already struggling with the winter flu season, but officials are isolating anyone with a history of travel to central China and those exhibiting respiratory tract infections that look similar to the virus.So far some 300 people have been tested and monitored for the virus. Quarantine centres have been set up in remote holiday parks for anyone found to have come into close contact with people who tested positive.On Saturday, officials announced a newly built but still-empty public housing block would be used for medical staff on the frontline who did not want to risk returning to their families.

Uganda has not had such an outbreak since the 1960s and is already on alert.The locusts also are moving steadily toward Ethiopia's Rift Valley, the breadbasket for Africa's second-most populous country, the UN says.'The situation is very bad but farmers are fighting it in the traditional way,' said Buni Orissa, a resident of Ethiopia's Sidama region.Â 'The locusts love cabbage and beans. This may threaten the shaky food security in the region.'Even before this outbreak, nearly 20million people faced high levels of food insecurity across the East African region long challenged by periodic droughts and floods.As exasperated farmers look for more help in fighting one of history's most persistent pests, the FAO's Locust Watch offers little consolation.'Although giant nets, flamethrowers, lasers and huge vacuums have been proposed in the past, these are not in use for locust control,' the U.N. agency says. title: How Netflix documentary Dont F Cats raises disturbing question
story: Share this article Deanna was appalled but, still determined to hunt down the kitten killer, helped form a breakaway group from among the more responsible Facebook investigators and redoubled her efforts.Â There was another leap forward when they received an anonymous tip that the perpetrator was a man called Luka Magnotta and they embarked on the laborious process of analysing the locations featured in his Facebook pictures.Using Google Maps, they pinpointed a block of flats where heâ€™d been living in Toronto, for example, although, frustratingly, Magnotta had already left.Deanna and her colleagues discovered that he had been born in Ontario and had changed his name from Eric Newman. Once a would-be model with high cheekbones and pouty lips, Magnotta had become obsessed with Hollywood, dedicating his life to pursuing stardom.Failing to find success in the fashion world, he became a stripper, appeared in gay porn videos and posted thousands of clearly photoshopped images of himself leading a jet-set lifestyle in glamorous locations around the world.Hungry for fame, Magnotta had set up at least 70 Facebook pages and 20 websites under different names, which he used to plant rumours about himself, including that he was in a relationship with a high-profile convicted murderer.But as the Facebook investigators closed in on their target, something else was starting to happen: Magnotta seemed to be feeding off the notoriety he was gaining. And as the focus upon him intensified, so his actions grew more extreme.Indeed, his next move was to release two further videos of him killing kittens â€“ one fed to a python and the other drowned in a bath while tied to the end of a pole.Then, revelling in the attention, Magnotta apparently confirmed to those hunting him that he was indeed the killer. Now Deanna feared that he might pose a threat to people, too.It is well known that some psychopaths kill animals before moving on to murder people, and in Deannaâ€™s view it was a race against time to bring him to justice.This was chillingly confirmed when Magnotta sent her a video taken as she walked through her place of work. â€˜I know who you are and I know where you work,â€™ Magnotta tells Deanna on the clip. Her own life was at risk.         Stabbed to death:Â Jun Lin was attacked by Luka Magnotta with a screwdriver.Â â€˜The more I read about Jun Lin, it hit me so hard that Iâ€™d worked 18 months to get this person stopped, and then he committed murder,â€™ Deanna said laterThe Facebook sleuths begged Magnotta to seek help, but to no avail. They made several attempts to pass their vast cache of evidence to Canadian police but heard nothing back â€“ until their worst fears proved correct.In 2012, Magnotta posted a new video, entitled 1 Lunatic, 1 Ice Pick. It showed a blurred figure stabbing a naked man 100 times with a screwdriver. The killer had moved on to humans.Â The screwdriver was painted silver, which it was later discovered had been to make it look like the ice pick used by Sharon Stoneâ€™s character in the erotic thriller Basic Instinct.A torso was found in a suitcase outside Magnottaâ€™s apartment in Montreal, along with binbags stained with blood, a dead puppy and Magnottaâ€™s ID.Â Any remaining doubts were dismissed when it turned out that Magnotta had been caught on CCTV casually disposing of the items and â€“ such was his narcissism â€“ checking his reflection on the way back into the building.Viewers are told that Magnotta dismembered the corpse â€“ although it is not clear how â€“ and that he sent various body parts to the headquarters of Canadaâ€™s two leading political parties.The killing of 33-year-old Jun Lin, a Chinese engineering student, had a devastating effect on Deanna. For all her efforts, she had been powerless to help.â€˜The more I read about Jun Lin, it hit me so hard that Iâ€™d worked 18 months to get this person stopped, and then he committed murder,â€™ she said later.Finally, Canadian police were obliged to act, sending Magnottaâ€™s details to forces around the world, and he was apprehended in Berlin on June 4, 2012, in an internet cafe.Â The owner recognised Magnotta from newspaper reports and flagged down a passing officer.Magnotta had been looking up his own mugshot on the Interpol website at the time.So reviled was the murderer that no airline company would fly him back to Montreal and a plane from the Royal Canadian Air Force had to be used instead.Â Magnotta's lawyers claimed he was schizophrenic but the prosecution argued that he had faked the condition and, instead, suffered borderline personality disorder.In December 2014, he was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison.Whatever the truth about his mental state, he showed little or no emotion when confronted with his crimes.Â â€˜You see him being given a photo of Jun Lin and he doesnâ€™t even react,â€™ says director Mark Lewis.Â â€˜He was far more focused on making it clear to people that he had been a model and an actor.â€™Deeply conflicted about the role they played in trying to track down Magnotta, Deanna and her group of online crusaders were initially wary about taking part in the Netflix documentary.They were haunted that Magnotta might not have resorted to murder had they not provided the very audience he seemed to crave.â€˜One of the things which keeps me up sometimes at night is, were we complicit in his crimes?â€™ she asks.Â â€˜Maybe I did exactly what the killer wanted. These people donâ€™t deserve our attention.â€˜There are so many people in society loving true crime and serial killer documentaries. Every killer has fans.â€˜People write to these guys in prison. Itâ€™s insane. I am guilty of that as well. I watch these documentaries. Iâ€™m in one now.â€™Deannaâ€™s campaign is far from over. Her group has launched an online organisation which seeks to alert local authorities to animal abusers and has played a role in a number of successful arrests.In the final moments of the documentary, however, she poses a troubling question about our ever-increasing fascination with true crime.â€˜You at home, watching a whole documentary about Luka Magnotta â€“ are you complicit?â€™ she asks, before concluding: â€˜Perhaps itâ€™s time we turned off the machine.â€™

title: book clinic what postmodernist novels should i read
story: Q: I love Ben Lerner. Can you please recommend some other good postmodernist writers?Keana Sierra, 23, Luthier, NorwayA: Alex Preston, an author, journalist and Observer critic, writes:Iâ€™m so glad you like Lerner. His latest, The Topeka School, seems to me to be doing something really fascinating: merging the playful po-mo metafictiveness of his first two novels with something more serious, authentic and heartfelt â€“ uplit with a beret and black turtleneck, if you will. It reminded me of David Foster Wallace at his best â€“ writing that demands something of the head and the heart. Infinite Jest might look weighty, but if you enjoyed The Topeka School, I think youâ€™d love it. For a shorter fix, try Brief Interviews With Hideous Men.Iâ€™m currently reading Jenny Offillâ€™s Weather (published next month by Granta), which is glorious. Sheâ€™s such a fine, funny writer, her observations shot through with luminous intelligence and emotional insight. Her last novel, Dept of Speculation, is also superb.Other writers who occupy a Ben Lerner-shaped space in my mind: Renata Adler (try Speedboat), Teju Cole (Open City), Roberto BolaÃ±o (The Savage Detectives), Sally Rooney (but youâ€™ve read her already, right?). You might also pick up David Shieldsâ€™s Reality Hunger, a book I love and loathe in equal measure it seems to me to speak to Lernerâ€™s project and the current state of the avant garde in interesting ways.Finally, I offer you Geoff Dyer, without whom Iâ€™m not sure Ben Lerner could exist. I like Dyerâ€™s nonfiction best â€“ Yoga for People Who Canâ€™t Be Bothered to Do It, White Sands and the mesmerising Out of Sheer Rage. His novel Jeff in Venice, Death in Varanasi is a scream. Enjoy!Submit your question for book clinic below or email bookclinic@observer

title: sydney bookstore says it was targeted by pickup artists from dating coaching company
story: Kinokuniya apologises to customers who felt harassed and warns clients from such companies are not welcomeA commercial â€œdating coachingâ€ company has been using a popular Sydney bookstore for its clients to test out predatory â€œpickupâ€ techniques.In an open letter published online, Kinokuniya Sydney said it had been made aware the unnamed dating coaching company â€œhas been using our store to give their clients practical experience, much to our dismayâ€.â€œWe apologise to any of our customers who have been approached in the store or had the negative experience of someone trying â€˜pickupâ€™ techniques with them.â€œAnd to anyone who has felt harassed we offer our deepest apologies. We have contacted the company we know is involved and requested they not enter the store again.â€The global emergence of commercial courses coaching men to be â€œpickup artistsâ€ has been widely condemned for teaching men who are unsuccessful in talking to or dating women to use psychological manipulation, intimidation and coercion in order to attract potential partners.Despite global opprobrium, the industry is estimated to be worth $100m a year and teaches manipulative techniques such as â€œneggingâ€ â€“ insulting a woman to undermine her confidence â€“ or â€œpeacockingâ€ â€“ dressing flamboyantly for attention (when actual peacocks do it, it is known as â€œlekkingâ€).The industry emerged into widespread public consciousness through journalist Neil Straussâ€™s 2005 book, The Game, which sold 2.5m copies but further iterations have been developed by self-styled pickup gurus such as Julien Blanc, whose visa to Australia was torn up after protests over videos published online demonstrating behaviours such as grabbing women by the throat, and forcing their heads towards his crotch, and Mystery (whose real name is Erik von Markovik).Online, readers praised Kinokuniyaâ€™s public statement to call out pickup artists and the commercial operations using their store.Writer Chloe Sargeant posted online that an apprentice â€œpickup artistâ€ had approached her in a bookstore.â€œToday a dude tried some classic The Game pickup artist lines on me at a bookstore, and started out with â€˜can you help me with a recommendation, what was your fave book of 2019?â€™ So I said Clementine Fordâ€™s Fight Like a Girl. He looked a bit flustered but persevered and was like â€˜oh no, I meant fiction!â€™â€œSo I said The Power by Naomi Alderman and when I explained what it was about he was like â€˜oh ... uh ... too scary for me, thanks anyway!â€™ and scurried away.â€œIâ€™ll add that Iâ€™d seen him try the same thing to two different women before me. Pickup artist stuff is so grim.â€Kinokinuya also issued a public warning to any other companies coaching men in â€œpickupâ€ techniques: â€œDonâ€™t come in.â€â€œOur staff and security have all been made aware that this has been happening and are on the lookout for anyone who is receiving unsolicited and unwanted attention.â€The store said anyone being harassed should speak with staff.â€œThat said, the bookstore should be a place for discussion and we donâ€™t want to discourage organic communications from taking place.â€œPlease come in, enjoy the books and the ideas, and enjoy sharing the space with other booklovers.â€

title: tracey thorn interview another planet memoir
story: The musician on rereading her teenage diaries and why sheâ€™s now a fervent fan of Jack ReacherTracey Thorn began her career as a singer and musician, before becoming best known as half of Everything But the Girl, with her lifelong partner, Ben Watt. She then became a solo artist, and a writer of three bestselling books: her 2013 memoir Bedsit Disco Queen, 2016â€™s Naked at the Albert Hall and Another Planet, published last year, which traces her years growing up in Londonâ€™s suburbs, and is out in paperback on 6 February.How does writing about the 1970s world of Another Planet feel now?My own kids canâ€™t imagine how we ever survived when I tell them about staying in all evening waiting for a phone call from someone, who youâ€™d then arrange to meet under a clock tower in a nearby town, only to have the bus cancelled and not be able to get there. The thing that strikes me now is how locally rooted our lives were. Without the internet, we had no access to other people in other places, so we did a lot of dreaming and a lot of fantasising. The rest of the time, we just tried to avoid dying of boredom.Your diaries fill the book. Theyâ€™re hilariously unpoetic: about clothes you failed to buy, Coronation Street episodes, unsuitable boys. What surprised you about them?How dishonest they are in places. Given that I was only writing them for myself, I didnâ€™t often take the opportunity to express my true feelings. Instead, I lied, and put on a brave face. â€œNever fancied him anyway,â€ Iâ€™d write when a boy dumped me. Iâ€™d leave out things that had gone wrong, or been difficult. I think it was partly an exercise in defiance, a refusal to be defeated by lifeâ€™s adversities. So in that sense, my diary was a bit of a self-help manual, written by me, for me.The book is also about your parents, and how wildly their lives and expectations differed from yours. You mention your father saying â€œI never knew Tracey was so into musicâ€ after you wrote your first memoir Bedsit Disco Queen. What was it like to trawl those memories?My dad barely features in my diaries, as I think we were quite distant at that time, which perhaps goes some way to explaining how little he knew or understood me. We werenâ€™t connecting, and I think he lost sight of who I really was. As for my mum, we had been very close, and then fell out badly when I rebelled against all the rules and conventions. Some of the diary entries I found very painful to read. Accounts of ugly rows. Tears and shouting. The casual way in which I mention that she has been put on Valium by the doctor.Another Planet celebrates female musicians that offered you a way out of ordinary life. How have the memoirs of several you mention â€“ like Viv Albertine and Chrissie Hynde â€“ inspired you?Itâ€™s been fantastic to hear the true life stories from those women. So often the story of rockâ€™nâ€™roll is told from a male perspective. So often it feels like men own music. And I still get as angry and frustrated about that as I ever did. Reading those womenâ€™s accounts of their lives has reminded me how much they paved the way back then. And history too often erases the women, in all art forms. Every single published story of a female artist goes a small way towards redressing the balance, and is another one saved from the fire.You write about pop stars that emerged from the boredom of suburbia, like David Bowie and Siouxsie Sioux. Do we need more boredom?No, I would never impose boredom on anyone. Life is short and itâ€™s a shame to spend some of it feeling trapped and thwarted. I know that it can be an inspiration to some people, and spur you on to make things happen, but at the same time it can also just drag you down. Sometimes it crushed our imaginative spirit. Sometimes it made us reckless, and for young girls that was risky. Weâ€™d do anything to escape being bored, and that wasnâ€™t always good for us.Which books about suburbia have you enjoyed?Hanif Kureishiâ€™s The Buddha of Suburbia is amazing. Also, when I had just finished writing Another Planet a book was published by John Grindrod called Outskirts: Living Life on the Edge of the Green Belt. I panicked and asked my publisher to read it for me, fearing that the book I had just written was going to be an exact copy of this one. Luckily it isnâ€™t, although I have only recently dared to look at it. It is very worth reading.Which writers did you like when were young that have stayed with you?My reading habits as a teenager were a bit skewed by trying to impress, if Iâ€™m being honest, boys. So I went through a phase of carrying Camus and Sartre under my arm, thinking that would be irresistible. I also fell hard for Kerouacâ€™s On the Road, which spoke to my yearning for freedom and travel and drugs and sex and all the rest of it. I darenâ€™t read it again now in case I donâ€™t like it any more. The writer I loved as a teen who has most stayed with me is George Orwell.Which genres do you particularly enjoy reading that might surprise us? Are there any you avoid?Quite recently I discovered Lee Childâ€™s Jack Reacher books and I have become a complete addict. I read the first four in what seems like a few fevered days, and I am looking forward to reading them all. Absolutely adore the economy, and the plotting, and the sheer sense of energy that runs through them.Whatâ€™s the last really great book you read?Dependency by Tove Ditlevsen, which is the third part of her Copenhagen Trilogy. She was born in 1917, a working-class girl in Copenhagen, and grew up longing to be a writer. These books tell the story of how she made that happen, but also her struggle with drugs and alcohol. Her writing is incredible, so focused and clear. Not a word that doesnâ€™t need to be there.What do you plan to read next?Iâ€™ve got a â€œto readâ€ pile in the kitchen, and on it at the moment are Funny Weather by Olivia Laing, The Living Mountain by Nan Shepherd, and The Days of Abandonment by Elena Ferrante.And what book would you give to a teenager?Iâ€™ve never liked being prescriptive with any of my kids. They should read whatever they fancy. Having said that, I just gave our 18-year-old Kevin Barryâ€™s Night Boat to Tangier and heâ€™s really enjoying it.â€¢ Another Planet by Tracey Thorn is published by Canongate (Â£9.99). To order a copy go to bookshop. Free UK p&ampp over Â£15

title: humpback whales bunny chow and golden beaches why you should visit durban
story: Desperate for a dose of winter sun? South Africaâ€™s Durban delivers 320 days of sunshine every year, as well as surfing, foodie adventures and sensational land and sea safariOnce seen as the quiet cousin of cosmopolitan Cape Town and fast-paced Johannesburg, the natural wonders and cultural charms of Durban and its surrounds put it firmly on South Africaâ€™s must-see map. Fly direct from London Heathrow to Durban with British Airways, then get exploring.The best place for a first-look at â€œDurbsâ€ â€“ as the locals call it â€“ is down on the Golden Mile, an iconic stretch (nearly three-miles long, not one, as its name would have you believe) of powdery beaches backed by a colourful pedestrian promenade, all of it smartened up for the 2010 World Cup.Shimmering off to the north is another legacy project of the tournament, the Moses Mabhida Stadium. An 80-metre freefall and 220-metre arc makes the Big Rush Big Swing from the stadium arch the worldâ€™s tallest swing, while the more sedate SkyCar delivers superb views of the city and its beaches.With miles of golden sand, and water that rarely dips below 20C, Durban richly deserves its reputation as South Africaâ€™s surfing capital. Surf schools on the promenade â€“ try Xpression or Learn 2 Surf â€“ will have you up and riding in no time. The smaller waves of South Beach are best for beginners, while expert surfers will delight in the long tubes of New Pier.From May to November, these seas are also home to humpback and southern right whales, while Brydeâ€™s, sperm and minke whales inhabit the oceans all year round. Look out for lobtailing, when a whale slaps its tail on the water to create waves, and breaching, when a whale launches out of the water as if ready to backflip. And that wasnâ€™t enough, you can often spot dolphins ing in the crests of the waves. Whale and Dolphin Tours offer daily aquatic safari cruises from Durban marina the company is committed to training tour guides from disadvantaged communities and supporting Whale Timeâ€™s environmental research.Oceans aside, Durban is giving Cape Town a run for its money when it comes to culinary adventures. On tree-lined Florida Road youâ€™ll find a neat cross section of the cityâ€™s resurgent kitchen creativity, from pan-African flavours at Dukkah to the ice-cream-filled macaroons of chef Zakeeya Mithaâ€™s Sugarlicious. The falooda-inspired Bombay crush ice-cream is the go-to here.But when it comes to dining, Durban is all about curry. Donâ€™t leave without braving the famous â€œbunny chowâ€: a quarter-loaf of white bread, hollowed out and filled with bean or mutton curry. Youâ€™ll find bunny chow across the city, but in Durban central the Oriental restaurant is an institution. A mutton bunny will set you back just R79.95 (Â£4.19).Itâ€™s also just a short walk from the colourful Victoria Street Market, where spice shops are piled high with fiery bespoke blends. Around the corner, the Juma Masjid is worth a look. Itâ€™s one of the largest mosques in the southern hemisphere, the domed facade completed in 1943.Thereâ€™s certainly plenty to keep you busy in the city, but as the capital of KwaZulu-Natal province Durban is also the perfect starting point for adventures farther afield. With public transport thin on the ground, an Avis rental car is your best bet.A 20-minute drive north of the city brings you to the seaside suburb of Umhlanga, long favoured by South African holidaymakers. Youâ€™ll want to spend time exploring the walking trails of the Umhlanga Lagoon Nature Reserve, or browsing the weekly Wednesday morning farmersâ€™ market, but first drop your bags at the Oyster Box hotel, an elegant grande dame of South Africaâ€™s seaside hotels. The pool terrace delivers impressive views â€“ of breaching whales and the ocean â€“ but the attentive staff will also happily set up deckchairs and umbrellas on the beach for you. And thereâ€™s no need to venture out in search of dinner: the generous curry buffet here is legendary. Beware the fiery beef vindaloo.Another 30 minutesâ€™ drive along the Dolphin Coast brings you to Zimbali Coastal Resort, where the Fairmont Zimbali Resort offers 154 luxury rooms, secluded beaches and easy access to the resortâ€™s excellent 18-hole golf course, which plays through lush coastal forest. Bring plenty of spare balls.South Africa is synonymous with safari, and Phinda Private Game Reserve and Hluhluwe-iMfolozi park are just two hoursâ€™ drive farther north, with a clutch of upscale safari lodges dishing up five-star luxury and Big Five sightings. As well as lions, leopards, rhinos, elephants and buffalo, you may even catch a glimpse of the elusive cheetah.Or head west from Durban, towards the rugged peaks of the Drakensberg mountains. The uKhahlamba-Drakensberg park was declared a world heritage site in 2000, noted for its ancient San rock art and rugged scenery. The historic battlefields of central KwaZulu-Natal are also within easy reach for travellers with a car, with talented guides bringing the drama and tragedy of the protracted Anglo-Zulu wars of the late-1800s to life.So now, the choice is yours. Battles? The Big Five? Beaches? Bunny chow? One thingâ€™s for certain, Durban is no longer second fiddle when it comes to cosmopolitan coastal escapes in South Africa.How to bookWith direct flights from London Heathrow to Durban, British Airways Holidays can help make your South Africa fly-drive unforgettable. Book with British Airways Holidays and Avis to benefit from a 24-hour holiday helpline, full Atol protection and deposits starting from just Â£75 per person.

title: south africas garden route discover the most scenic spots
story: From barnacle-encrusted whales to sweeps of blooming fynbos, the south-eastern coast of South Africa offers the ultimate picturesque road tripSouth Africaâ€™s Garden Route is almost obscenely good-looking. The meandering drive â€“ stretching more than 120 miles from Mossel Bay in the west, to Storms River in the east â€“ takes in dappled forests, still lakes and surf-pummeled beaches. Itâ€™s best explored on four wheels, but be sure to take your time. British Airways flies direct to Cape Town, where you can pick up an Avis hire car, belt up and settle into a truly picturesque ride.Humpback whales can often be spotted breaching clear out of the water at Hermanus, just a 90-minute drive from Cape Town. You can even spot whales lolling metres from the shoreline â€“ keep your ears primed for the huff of a humpback whale exhaling right by your feet. The town hosts an annual whale festival each September â€“ when huge southern right whales pass by in large numbers â€“ and thereâ€™s even a whale crier, who alerts crowds to the presence of the animals by blowing on a kelp horn. July to October is a great time to see pods of migrating mothers with their calves and, if youâ€™re feeling languid, the Marine Hotel is perfectly situated on a clifftop overlooking the ocean, so youâ€™ll be able to spot barnacle-clad beasts from your balcony.A 40-minute trundle down the road, youâ€™ll find Gansbaai. Known by locals as the Serengeti of the sea, the waters here are bristling with sea creatures, including the marine big five: whales, dolphins, seals, penguins and sharks. The latter can be seen in their menacing masses in Shark Alley â€“ a sliver of ocean that roils with cape fur seals, the great whiteâ€™s favourite prey.Itâ€™s a four-hour journey from Gansbaai to Oudtshoorn, but youâ€™ll have plenty of screensaver scenery to gawp at along the way, including the craggy Tradouw mountain pass and the twisty-turny Huisrivier pass, which clings to the side of a mountain where cape leopards still roam. As well as the Cango Caves â€“ an impressive prehistoric limestone system, dripping with troll-like rock formations, stalagmites and stalactites â€“ Oudtshoorn boasts the largest number of ostriches in the world, with many of the farms offering tractor rides or walks out in the fields with the colossal birds.Head almost due south towards the coast and youâ€™ll soon reach Knysna â€“ a charming holiday town right at the heart of the Garden Route. Here, youâ€™ll find a vast aquamarine lagoon spilling out into the ocean from between two huge sandstone headlands, helpfully known as the Heads. Hike through the lush forest â€“ thought of as the lungs of this beautiful town â€“ or take a trip out on to the water where you can fish, kayak, water ski and swim.A half-hour drive east is Plettenberg Bay. Home to the rocky Robberg Nature Reserve â€“ where you can snorkel with rambunctious seals â€“ a satisfyingly sandy central beach and the Nelson Bay caves, which date back to the stone age. This is also a great place to take part in a township tour (run by Ocean Blue Adventures). Meet up with a local from the Qolweni community and join them on a visit to the townshipâ€™s Siyakhula crÃ¨che, the central shebeen and other lively spots, meeting some of the friendly locals and learning about the townshipâ€™s rich history along the way. Come evening, stay at the remarkable Tsala Treetop Lodge just out of town â€“ a collection of elegant elevated hideaways decked out in Afro-baroque style and hidden among the canopy of the ancient indigenous forest.Locals like to call Tsitsikamma, just north of Storms River â€“ â€œthe garden of the Garden Routeâ€. An old Khoisan word, Tsitsikamma means â€œplace of much waterâ€, and whether itâ€™s the yawning river valleys, the flinty ocean or the dew-daubed forest that clings to the mountains, this place is most certainly lush. Don your hiking boots for a lung-cleansing hike around this beautiful landscape, then make your final drive to Storms River, where â€“ if the mood strikes â€“ you can mark the end of your epic road trip by hurling yourself off the Bloukrans Bridge â€“ the worldâ€™s highest bridge to bungee off.How to bookWith direct flights from London to Cape Town, British Airways Holidays can help make your South Africa fly-drive unforgettable. Book with British Airways Holidays and Avis to benefit from a 24-hour holiday helpline, full Atol protection and deposits starting from just Â£75 per person.

title: david attenborough citizens climate assembly
story: People from across Britain will join TV host to discuss ways to cut emissions to zero by 2050Sir David Attenborough will address members of the public who are taking part in the UKâ€™s first climate assembly this weekend.The TV presenter and naturalist will appear in Birmingham, where the 110 members are meeting to address how to reduce emissions to zero by 2050, to thank them for taking part.â€œI am grateful to the 110 people from all corners of the United Kingdom who are giving up their weekends to take part in this very important discussion,â€ Attenborough said.â€œThese people have been picked to represent our population as a whole, they come from all walks of life, and together they will deliberate carefully on behalf of us all. We should listen closely to their recommendations.â€The climate assembly has been set up along the lines of the citizensâ€™ assembly in France, instituted by the president, Emmanuel Macron.The assembly was selected to be a representative sample of the population after a mail-out to 30,000 people chosen at random. About 2,000 people responded saying they wanted to be considered for the assembly, and the 110 members were picked by computer.The UK climate assembly differs from the French model in that it was commissioned by six select committees, rather than by the prime minister. Its views, which will be produced in a report in the spring, will be considered by the select committees but there is no guarantee the government will take up any of the proposals.The assembly will meet for four weekends this spring. On the third weekend it will begin making decisions about ways to meet the net-zero target.Prominent business, faith and civil society leaders from across the UK have sent messages of support to the assembly.Prof Lord Krebs, a former member of the climate change committee, said: â€œClimate change is the defining issue of our time. Without action now, we will leave an uninhabitable planet for our children and their children.â€œThe climate assembly will play a key role in helping to inform all who need to take action: iniduals, businesses, local government and community groups and, crucially, central government.â€

title: cacao not gold chocolate trees offer future to amazon tribes aoe
story: In Brazilâ€™s largest indigenous reserve thousands of saplings have been planted as an alternative to profits from illegal gold miningThe villagers walk down the grassy landing strip, past the wooden hut housing the health post and into the thick forest, pointing out the seedlings they planted along the way. For these Yeâ€™kwana indigenous men, the skinny saplings, less than a metre high, arenâ€™t just baby cacao trees but green shoots of hope in a land scarred by the violence, pollution and destruction wrought by illegal gold prospecting. That hope is chocolate.â€œWe want to plant and develop income for the community,â€ says JÃºlio Yeâ€™kwana, 39, president of the Yeâ€™kwana peopleâ€™s Wanasseduume association, which came up with the idea. â€œAnd it is not destructive for the forest.â€In the last two years, thousands of Theobroma cacao trees have been planted near WaikÃ¡s and other villages in the remote Yanomami indigenous reserve. The saplings were planted within the forest because cacao likes shade, an idea borrowed from agroforestry techniques successfully used for cacao elsewhere in the Amazon.Villagers hope that within a few years rich, organic chocolate will be produced from the golden cacao fruit these trees bear. The project â€“ run by the reserveâ€™s indigenous associations Wanasseduume and Hutukara with Brazilian non-profit group Instituto Socioambiental (ISA) â€“ is ambitious, but experts say it is based on a potential commercial reality.Located in the far north of the Brazilian Amazon, Yanomami is Brazilâ€™s biggest indigenous reserve, spread over 9.6 million hectares (23.7m acres). But its wild, mountainous forests are overrun by an estimated 20,000 wildcat goldminers, called garimpeiros.Yeâ€™kwana and Yanomami indigenous leaders called for the garimpeiros to be expelled with a letter and group photo later shared by actor Leonardo DiCaprio.But the countryâ€™s far-right president, Jair Bolsonaro, has claimed that indigenous people really yearn for white societyâ€™s consumer lifestyles, said the Yanomami reserve is too big for its population and may be sued for racism by the Brazilian Indigenous Peopleâ€™s Association after comments during a Facebook Live broadcast this week. â€œThe indigenous changed, they are evolving,â€ he said. â€œMore and more the indigenous are human beings equal to us.â€â€œThe president says indigenous people are poor. We are not poor. Nobody goes hungry here,â€ says JÃºlio Yeâ€™kwana. â€œWe eat for free.â€ was invited to visit by the Hutukara Yanomami Association, founded by Davi Kopenawa, a leader and shaman who fought to create the reserve with photographer Claudia Andujar and non-profit group Survival International.Five villages from both tribes are participating in the cacao project. Cacao trees are native in this area, but around 3,000 new seedlings have been planted to boost production, with 7,000 expected by the end of 2021.Edmilson EstevÃ£o shins up a mature cacao tree to bring down some of the heavy yellow fruit. Inside each thick shell is a sticky cluster of seeds, packed in a sweet, delicious, pale paste. These are dried and roasted to make chocolate.â€œOne tree like this can bear up to 20 fruit,â€ says EstevÃ£o, 33, who was raised in WaikÃ¡s and works for Wanasseduume.These mature trees were planted more than a decade ago by Luiz Yeâ€™kwana. He was murdered by garimpeiros after refusing to transport them upriver, villagers say.Violence is a recurrent problem around garimpeiros, as becomes graphically evident the next day. Outside the health post, two garimpeiros are wrapping a dead body in a tarpaulin. The dead man was known as Eduardo at TatuzÃ£o, the illegal gold mining camp two hoursâ€™ boat ride upstream. But everybody uses an alias there. The nurse who fought to save his life discovered that his real name was Ralf Cabral and he was 21. The garimpeiros say he shot himself.His eyes are wide open, he is dressed in black football shorts, and there is a bandage over the bullet hole in his chest. â€œHeâ€™s been here for five months, and now heâ€™s done this,â€ says Manoel dos Santos, 49, wrapping Cabralâ€™s body. â€œI have no idea why.â€The health post was built by the Brazilian government to serve the villageâ€™s 150 Yeâ€™kwana people, but also handles hundreds of garimpeiro cases each year, including miscarriages, malaria, snake bites, broken limbs, knife and gunshot wounds. â€œItâ€™s a war here,â€ says Giselle Dornellas, 33, the nurse who kept Cabral alive for 12 hours.Garimpo gold is seductive and buys televisions and phones. Four villagers work as boat pilots, others deliver food, and even the village community centre was built with garimpo money.But the cacao project will offer an alternative, says its coordinator, ISA anthropologist Moreno Saraiva. â€œWeâ€™re trying to build another possible future,â€ he says. â€œIt will take five years, but if we donâ€™t do this now there will never be another alternative.â€The project was inspired by another ISA project that since 2016 has produced edible mushrooms in other Yanomami villages. On paper the cacao project makes sense. Most of the worldâ€™s cacao production is in Africa, but the plant is native to the Amazon and was domesticated in South America 4,000 years ago. The Aztecs used the beans as money. And a Spanish map from 1775 called the Yanomami area the â€œPais de los cacagualesâ€ â€“ or â€œCacao Landâ€.â€œYou have a traditional and well-spread presence of native cocoa trees,â€ says food researcher Roberto Smeraldi, vice-president of the AtÃ¡ Institute founded by Alex Atala â€“ the Michelin starred Brazilian chef renowned for using ingredients from the Amazon.Smeraldi recruited CÃ©sar de Mendes, a chocolate specialist based near the Amazon city of BelÃ©m for the cacao project. ISA and the indigenous associations organised well-attended workshops with de Mendes in WaikÃ¡s in 2018 and 2019 to show villagers how cacao seeds are processed to make chocolate.Fruit from mature Yanomami cacao trees was used to produce a trial run. A thousand 50g bars of the bitter, delicious Yanomami chocolate quickly sold out at an event in SÃ£o Paulo last December, despite a Â£9.20 price tag. Customers were happy to pay to compensate for the destruction caused by garimpo, de Mendes says. Profits went to both indigenous associations.â€œI am not being much of a businessman, I am being more an activist,â€ de Mendes says. â€œWe are selling to an aware public.â€He learned his trade from his grandmother, who made her own chocolate in an Amazon riverside community, and singles out the Yanomami chocolateâ€™s notes of almond oil and flowers, light acidity and sweetness. â€œThese give this cacao its own personality,â€ he says.Smeraldi argues that the Yanomami cacaoâ€™s origins in this isolated jungle could make its genetic properties attractive to the world cacao industry, which is vulnerable to climate change and blights such as the witchesâ€™ broom fungus which ravaged cacao plantations in the state of Bahia three decades ago.And the chocolateâ€™s strong, persistent taste could find its niche in the booming, specialist chocolate market, he says. Distinct fruits and flavours are increasingly sought out, as happened with wine when customers graduated from ordering â€œredâ€ or â€œwhiteâ€ to specific grapes and countries. â€œIt is a product of high complexity,â€ Smeraldi says.But Bolsonaroâ€™s government is heading in the opposite direction. It is sending a bill to Congress to legalise garimpo, which the energy minister, Admiral Bento Albuquerque, recently presented to European diplomats.The news chills villagers in WaikÃ¡s. â€œIf Bolsonaro succeeds, itâ€™s the end for our people,â€ says Eduardo da Silva, 65. But it has also bolstered support for the cacao project.â€œWe have to do it for our children, not for us,â€ says Felipe Gimenes, 45, the village schoolteacher and former chief who planted an extra 200 cacao seedlings on his own plot. â€œThis is our opportunity.â€Find more age of extinction coverage here, and follow bioersity reporters Phoebe Weston and Patrick Greenfield on Twitter for all the latest news and features

title: climate change election 2020 youth activism
story: Young demonstrators aim to make the climate crisis a central issue of the presidential campaignOrganizers in the youth climate movement plan an avalanche of activities beginning next week, determined to make the future of the climate the major issue of the 2020 election.Capitalizing on turnout in the September climate strikes, when 6 million people worldwide turned out to demand urgent action to address the escalating ecological emergency, young US organizers are making the leap from mobilization to demands. Theyâ€™re planning widespread voter activation in the 2020 US presidential election as well as direct action targeting the fossil fuel industry and the banks and politicians that enable it.â€œThe headline message of the strikes in 2020 is: the kids are taking to the streets to strike for climate and theyâ€™re asking you to vote,â€ said Katie Eder, the executive director of Future Coalition, a communications and training hub for youth climate groups.There are more than 300 organizations involved in the efforts, Eder said, including some of the largest youth and adult coalitions in climate movement: Fridays for Future, the Sunrise Movement, 350.org, Zero Hour, Extinction Rebellion.â€œWeâ€™re starting to have the conversation within the strikes about how weâ€™re balancing both the political targets and the financial targets,â€ Eder said, calling power and money â€œreally key to the root causes of why weâ€™re not addressing climate changeâ€.Activists have planned widespread voter mobilization campaigns three days of national strikes, marches, and direct action against politicians and banks beginning on Earth Day (22 April) regular strikes on Fridays and additional strikes targeting primary elections in every state plus an international day of action, college estment campaigns, and a huge push by the Sunrise Movement to turn out the vote for Bernie Sanders and a Green New Deal.Stories of climate awakening are a universal truth for young Americans living in the age of worsening climate conditions. Isabella Fallahi, who has asthma, for example, has lived within 14 miles of a coal-burning generating facility all of her life.â€œA lot of people donâ€™t think of Indiana, or the midwest, for that matter, as frontline communities,â€ she said. â€œWe face the silent killers. The terrible air quality because of mining projects, the terrible water quality because of mining projects, the health effects associated with both of those, droughts that cripple the agricultural economies that weâ€™re based off of.â€But Fallahi, like many other young organizers, is also galvanized by the tech proficiency of her generation, born into the era of hashtags and the ubiquitous touchscreen. She was a speaker at the UN climate change conference in Madrid (COP 25) in December 2019, when she and other youth were nearly ejected for protesting against the fossil fuel executives on panels and in negotiations.Approximately 200 young people in 40 countries, many of whom were at the conference, organized a response called Polluters Out. In 20 days, they had a website, a multilingual launch video, a press release in seven languages, and a list of demands. In actions set for March, they will call for the exclusion of fossil fuel interests at COP26 and transparency in the UN framework on climate change, as well as inclusion of indigenous and human rights in the Paris agreement. Regional efforts in the US will also call for a Green New Deal, a halt to new fossil fuel infrastructure, estments from fossil fuels by universities and campaign funds, and the targeting of specific banks for fossil fuel investments.The groups stay in touch through conference calls, Slack, Zoom, and Google Drive. Activists in Cuba â€“ who canâ€™t download the apps because of the US trade embargo â€“ tune in through WhatsApp. Thereâ€™s a Slack channel for supporting scientists, too. And meetings wait for organizers in the Amazon who need to travel to towns for internet access.For all of them, there is community. People to cry with over the photo of the bay in Australia, so covered in smoke that it is hardly visible.â€œOverall, I think the way to look at this perspective on the youth movement is: it is cohesive in that they do communicate, but the orgs are not all the same,â€ said Natalie Mebane, associate director of US Policy for 350.org and an adult mentor for Zero Hour, both organizations intensely focused on voter turnout for climate for 2020. â€œWe want to make sure that climate becomes the number one issue on votersâ€™ minds.â€The Sunrise Movement, like 350.org and Zero Hour, has taken that to a grassroots level. That is how Naina Agrawal-Hardin ended up in the guidance office at Washtenaw high school outside Ann Arbor, Michigan, for an interview. Sheâ€™s a leader for the Ann Arbor hub of the Sunrise Movement. And sheâ€™s 16, a junior. Her school, she said, was supportive.â€œWhenever I have to take conference calls or interviews during school hours, they usually will write me a pass to get out of class,â€ she said.Agrawal-Hardin is planning a watch party at her home â€“ a sneak peek at the forthcoming documentary Generation Green New Deal and a video about the Sunrise Movementâ€™s 2020 campaign, as part of its annual kickoff. Sunrise provides the documentaries, discussion questions, and near-daily training on organizing and recruitment techniques. When Agrawal-Hardin hosts her event on 29 January, sheâ€™ll be one of more than 2,000 hosts nationwide.Through 2020, the Sunrise Movement will similarly activate its 300 chapters in support of Bernie Sanders, leveraging 10,000 volunteers in most of the 50 states for door knocks, voting pledges and climate education. Sunrise endorsed Sanders as the best-positioned candidate to lead a Green New Deal and address income inequality.â€œBy primarycaucus day in Iowa and New Hampshire, we are going to have over 20,000 young people who have signed pledges to vote for Green New Deal championsâ€ in the two states, said Sofie Karasek, a Sunrise Movement spokesperson. â€œWhat weâ€™re really expecting to see in 2020 is Young Green New Deal voters really become the margin of victory for whoever becomes the Democratic nominee.â€

title: melina matsoukas interview director queen and slim
story: The Queen &amp Slim director on working with BeyoncÃ©, filming in a polar vortex and being told that casting a black woman in a lead role isnâ€™t profitableMelina Matsoukas, 39, directed some of the most acclaimed music videos of the 2010s, including Rihannaâ€™s We Found Love, Solangeâ€™s Losing You and BeyoncÃ©â€™s Formation, for which she won a Grammy. She has also directed episodes of TV shows Master of None and Insecure. Her debut feature film, Queen &amp Slim, is written by Lena Waithe and stars Jodie Turner-Smith and Daniel Kaluuya as an African American couple on a first date who are forced to go on the run when one shoots a white police officer in self-defence. Matsoukas was born in New York, lives in Los Angeles, and is of Greek, Jewish, Afro-Cuban and Afro-Jamaican descent.The film is also a love story. What stories of black love did you grow up with?I didnâ€™t really feel like I grew up seeing two dark-skinned people fall in love on screen. I had never really seen that connection between two people who looked like our Queen and Slim, like Jodie and Daniel. I really wanted to be part of redefining what black beauty â€“ well, beauty â€“ means. I also think about when I went to film school and they said: â€œHey, casting a black woman as your lead wonâ€™t be profitable.â€Who said that to you?One of my teachers. They said it to the entire class, not just me, but Iâ€™m sitting in the class looking around like: â€œNo one else heard this?!â€ That really stuck with me.Your parents were very politically active. Is that something you inherited?My parents were definitely activists. I was brought up going to marches and fighting and understanding that we all have a purpose in life and we need to use our privilege to bring equality to the world.How does one navigate a polar vortex?Every 15 minutes weâ€™d have to go inside and drink soup and take breaks so people wouldnâ€™t get frostbite. One day we couldnâ€™t even shoot outside, we had to rig the car inside a warehouse. The equipment was failingâ€¦ It was actually horrendous.You started out directing music videos. What did you learn from that part of your career?From music videos, thereâ€™s a stigma this isnâ€™t true film-making. That genre isnâ€™t respected in the same way. Had I started out making a short film or even doing commercials, I feel like my career would have taken a different route. But I think itâ€™s really great training for understanding how to build a world.I hear youâ€™re a bit of a foodie. What was the last great meal you ate?Yes! I just had an incredible birthday dinner on Tuesday at Majordomo, which is David Changâ€™s restaurant in LA. They have this flatbread with this incredible butter with honey and cracked pepper â€“ the rest of the meal was heaven-sent, but that bread alone...In the movie, Slim asks: â€œWhy do black people always feel the need to be excellent?â€ Do you also feel that pressure yourself?Yeah, absolutely, I think thatâ€™s something that all black people can relate to. The opportunities are few and far between, and when weâ€™re given them we have to deliver and be prepared for them in a way that our white counterparts donâ€™t. Thereâ€™s this incredible burden to carry our community and make room not just for ourselves but for the next person, and the way to do that is by being excellent.Queen &amp Slim is out on 31 January

title: scott parker fulham old school values social media fa cup
story: Fulhamâ€™s manager has old-school values but understands the effects toxic social media can have on his playersâ€œI used a psychologist when I was playing,â€ Scott Parker says. â€œItâ€™s one of the most powerful things: how you can have a concrete head and not let things in. Of course thereâ€™s a technical element but nine times out of 10 when youâ€™re having a bad day it will mainly be mental: the mistake youâ€™ve made, the comment youâ€™ve heard, the crowdâ€™s reaction to a shot over the bar â€“ after that the fearâ€™s coming in.â€The mind fascinates Parker. Fulhamâ€™s manager wants to understand the human psyche. He aims to give his players resilience and the tools to think clearly under pressure. â€œYou have your first 10 touches and kick it into the stand, thereâ€™s a technical element,â€ he says. â€œBut what makes the 11th touch go in the stand again? Itâ€™s probably because the crowd are on me. You need to think: â€˜Let me go back to basics and build.â€™ It starts in your head and taking a deep breath.â€Less than a year into his first management job Parker understands how fear takes hold. As a youngster at Charlton he was carefree. That changed when he moved to Chelsea in 2004. The pressure was hard and it did not become any easier when he joined Newcastle in 2006.â€œI started to struggle,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™d go out every day on the grass and train my left foot. Iâ€™d try and get as fit as I could. But there are certain elements in games where itâ€™s nothing to do with technique. Itâ€™s more: â€˜I was training today and was really sloppy in the way I was.â€™ I took it into coaching.â€œThese boys are only human and at times there are 30,000 screaming at you. Now theyâ€™ve got the added pressure of going into the changing room and the first thing you see them do is click on their phone and Twitter comes up. You donâ€™t know the effect itâ€™s having on players but itâ€™s at the forefront of my mind. When I was playing it was a newspaper report. Now itâ€™s a whole new dynamic. You type your name in and nine times out of 10 itâ€™s negative.â€œWe do live in a world where with the click of a button youâ€™ve got something on your doorstep. I talk a lot about earning the right to take a picture of yourself. Earn the right to be a top player, earn the right to win a trophy. Thereâ€™s so much money in what weâ€™re doing and added to that is a social media platform where with one picture you can pretend to be whoever you want to be. In reality is it really like that?â€At 39 years old and the father of four boys, Parker is an interesting mix. He has old-school values and hates the falseness and toxicity of social media. At the same time, however, he is empathetic, inquisitive and flexible enough to build connections with his players.The former England midfielder â€“ he won 18 caps from 2003-13 â€“ was thrown in at the deep end, appointed on a caretaker basis when Fulham sacked Claudio Ranieri last March. Relegation from the Premier League was a certainty but the club saw enough to give Parker the job permanently.The early signs are promising for Fulham, who visit Manchester City in the FA Cup on Sunday. They are third in the Championship, three points behind second-placed Leeds, and Parker speaks enthusiastically about building for the long term. As a player he was everywhere. As a manager he wants standards to be high across the board.At the start of pre-season Parker commissioned an external company to assess his squadâ€™s personality. â€œWe profiled every player on how they want to be addressed, where they sit, certain spectrums of their personality in that sense,â€ he says. â€œWe did that so as a manager I have a rough idea of: â€˜This is what heâ€™s like, he doesnâ€™t like a brutal honest conversation, he doesnâ€™t want to be exposed in front of his peers.â€™â€œThose little snippets give me a lot of info because now, if Iâ€™m dealing with a player I need to sanction, I have a rough idea of where I need to get. The players understood weâ€™re all different. What Joe Bryan accepts and what Kevin McDonald or Harry Arter accept is very different and we need to understand we canâ€™t all be like this.â€Parker has reintegrated Aboubakar Kamara, who was arrested at Fulhamâ€™s training ground last January. The striker signed a new contract last month. â€œAt times you have to manage him very differently from some of the others,â€ Parker says. â€œBut Iâ€™ve not had a problem. I wouldnâ€™t accept having a big problem with him either.â€Accepting that footballers have changed is part of the challenge. â€œI donâ€™t see as much of a resilience any more,â€ Parker says. â€œI look at my kids sometimes and itâ€™s so easy to jump from one ship to the next. Itâ€™s easy to say: â€˜If thatâ€™s not working, letâ€™s get on to something else.â€™ Thereâ€™s going to be some bumps along the way but youâ€™ve got to keep going for it again.â€œThere are core values about how you conduct yourself, your work ethic and having a real passion about what you do. Theyâ€™re core values that will always stick with me and Iâ€™ll always use in the modern day.â€œTheyâ€™re the traits I need to instil in my players even more because I realise theyâ€™re probably deficient in them because theyâ€™ve not been around them as much as I have. Can I give them something which I know will make them better? And vice versa. Iâ€™m not on social media. At times I donâ€™t know how quickly the worldâ€™s moving and Iâ€™m constantly having to check. I suppose Iâ€™m trying to learn some bits from this new generation.â€â€œEvery day can you drive yourself to improve? Every day can you drive others? In the good teams and the best players I played with thatâ€™s what they had: self-drive. You donâ€™t expect to play. Thereâ€™s a fear about being dropped. A fear of not performing. Fear drives them on.â€

title: west ham david moyes fa cup west brom

title: fifa football global elite more money club world cup
story: The tournament will begin in its new expanded format in summer 2021 and already it has forced the Africa Cup of Nations to be re-rescheduledTippi Hedren sits on a bench outside the school. Behind her, crows gradually settle on a climbing frame. She smokes, distracted. By the time she finally notices a crow pass above her, it is too late. The frame, the roofs behind, the telegraph pole, the fence are laden with crows and the attack on the children cannot be averted. This is the greatest scene of Alfred Hitchcockâ€™s The Birds and it is also modern football.Every week, there comes a new detail, stat or report of an initiative. Inidually they can be laughed off. Whatâ€™s the Juventus chairman Andrea Agnelli banging on about this time? Who is Fifaâ€™s Gianni Infantino abasing himself in front of now at Davos? Why has the Spanish Super Cup been rejigged with wildly variant appearance fees to try to put on a Clasico for the people of Jeddah? Whatâ€™s the point of the Champions League group stage?The richest clubs are getting richer within leagues, but the richest leagues are also getting richer in comparison with other leagues. The knockout rounds of this seasonâ€™s Champions League feature clubs from the five major western European leagues. The last 32 of the Europa League features three clubs from eastern Europe.The past four World Cup winners are all wealthy western European powers (only hapless England remain aloof and even they are improving). Players in those countries grow up with supreme facilities in a highly competitive environment, which may not be without problems but does tend to produce good footballers â€“ as further demonstrated by Spain and Germanyâ€™s domination of Uefa youth tournaments.Yet the rich demand more. This month it was reported the European Club Association wants four additional matchdays in the Champions League. Within a week, Pep Guardiola was calling for the abolition of the League Cup to ease the pressure on players. Manchester Cityâ€™s manager may not agree with the ECA, but it hardly matters.The various plans to streamline the FA Cup follow a similar pattern: having already enriched the rich to the point the smaller clubs can barely compete, the smaller clubs are to be starved of fixtures that generate revenue so the elite can play each other more often and make even more money for themselves.Then thereâ€™s the Club World Cup, scheduled to begin in its new expanded format in summer 2021. It is not yet clear European clubs will compete but already the tournament has forced the Africa Cup of Nations to be re-rescheduled from June-July to January-February to avoid a clash.Until last year, that is when the Cup of Nations had traditionally been played before it was moved so as not to interfere with western European club seasons.The Confederation of African Football â€“ which has essentially been run by Fifa since the beginning of August â€“ insists the switch is a specific issue to do with the weather in Cameroon in June. But Cameroonâ€™s climate is not dissimilar to that of Ivory Coast, which will host in 2023. Average June temperature and humidity is much the same in YaoundÃ© and Abidjan, but June rainfall is almost double in Abidjan. If the rainy season is the issue, the argument to move the 2023 tournament is much stronger. Midâ€‘January 2023, though, is three weeks after the World Cup final in Qatar. Itâ€™s almost as if African football isnâ€™t the main consideration.Fifaâ€™s Infantino, in admittedly vague terms, has spoken of plans for a pan-African league to generate revenue, raise the standard of football across the continent and slow the drain of talent to Europe. That sounds a noble aim and if Fifaâ€™s Club World Cup is to prosper, it requires strong clubs from across the globe. But a super league is a super league and a little probing suggests the idea would be for a closed format. Which raises an immediate question: if you are in effect franchising a league across Africa, can you afford Al Ahly and Zamalek, Hearts of Oak and Kotoko, Orlando Pirates and Kaizer Chiefs or would the great rivalries that have energised football for generations be lost? Not to mention the impact on clubs slightly further down the pyramid.But perhaps that impact is coming anyway. If European clubs are to play in the Club World Cup, it will require enormous sums of money (the source of which raises a host of ethical concerns). The talk is of Â£40m-50m just to take part, with a prize fund on top. That will further widen the gulf between rich and poor in Europe, but elsewhere, even if clubs from other confederations get less, the distortion will be seismic.To take just one example, TP Mazembe, who have won seven of the past nine league titles in DR Congo and three of the past 11 African Champions Leagues, have an annual budget of around Â£8.5m. What happens to Congolese league football when the dominant side is supercharged by the revenues of the Club World Cup?The same pattern, the same enrichment of the rich, the same profanation of domestic leagues, the same shift to a quasi-franchise model is happening everywhere. It could happen globally. The Club World Cup is not about football. Itâ€™s about profit, because everything is these days, and Fifaâ€™s battle with Europeâ€™s governing body, Uefa, for control â€“ the gameâ€™s regulators become financial competitors.People donâ€™t want to believe. They want to think their club is different. They want simply to watch the game. Havenâ€™t the rich always been dominant? Yes, but to nothing like this extent. What about little Atalanta pipping oligarch-owned Shakhtar? Yes, there are exceptions. Itâ€™s football: random stuff still very occasionally happens Leicesterâ€™s Premier League title in 2016 is the greatest propaganda the superclubs could ever have dreamed up.Wake up! Turn around, have a look at that climbing frame and ask if this is what you want football to be.
